title: EP 291 Jeff Sebo on Who Matters, What Matters, and Why

rawLines.text: howdy this is Jim rut and this is the
Jim rut
[Music]
show listeners have asked us to provide
pointers to some of the resources we
talk about on the show we now have links
to books and articles referenced in
recent podcasts that are available on
our website we also offer full
transcripts go to Jim row.com that's Jim
row.com
today's guest is Jeff sibo Jeff's a
philosopher and ethicist focused on the
moral status of nonhuman beings
environmental ethics and our
responsibilities in the face of global
challenges he's an associate professor
at NYU and where he works on things that
are least relevant to this discussion
moral philosophy legal philosophy and
philosophy of Mind animal and AI minds
and related questions in ethics and
policy welcome Jeff hi Jim thanks for
having me yeah I'm looking forward to
this conversation uh we're going to be
talking today mostly though no doubt it
will head off into other directions as
well Jeff's relatively recent book the
moral Circle who matters what matters
and why it's quite brief I think about
140 pages of actual texts but I found
myself uh thinking a lot and wrote down
many notes in fact I was telling Jeff in
the pregame it may be the record or if
not in the top five of notes per
page well that is awesome I'll take it
all right and our topic today is who
matters and why basically one of your
core ideas is the idea of a moral Circle
why don't you start off by telling us
what you mean when you talk about a
moral
Circle yeah great place to start the
moral circle is a philosophical metaphor
for the scope of our moral Community who
belong in our moral community and a way
to think about that is to whom are we
accountable to whom do we have
responsibilities when we want to think
about the ethics of our actions whose
interests are we considering and so when
we ask about the scope of the moral
Circle we are asking how many beings
should we consider when when we think
about the harms that our actions might
be causing others or the risk that our
actions might be imposing on others and
historically of course especially in the
west our moral circles have tended to be
fairly narrow we have tended to extend
consideration to select humans maybe the
occasional charismatic Companion Animal
but these days at least many of us
recognize we should extend consideration
to many more beings than that at the
very least all humans and many animals
like mammals and birds affected by our
activity and then this book is asking
should we go even farther than that
should we extend consideration to an
even larger number and even wider range
of beings than that and if so how far
should we go and what should the details
be and what follows for our actions and
our policies and our priorities yeah and
you make a distinction right up front
you say take the difference between cats
and cars cats unlike cars have the
capacity to be harmed and wronged if I
kick a cat then I harm and wrong the cat
in contrast if I kick a car then I might
damage the car it may harm or wrong the
owner but there's no sense in which I
can harm or wrong the car maybe pick
that apart a little bit why those two
things yeah that is an example that is
supposed to give you an intuition about
the distinction and and the reason we
use those kinds of examples is that
there are a lot of types of value in the
world and a lot of ways of valuing
everyone and everything right so we
might for example value not only
artifacts like cars but also natural
systems like plants and trees and rivers
and and so on and so forth because of
the instrumental value that they provide
for us they have aesthetic value we find
them beautiful they have cultural value
we find them meaningful they have
ecological value or economic value we
depend on them in in in various ways but
this is a separate kind of value the the
topic of this book is a separate kind of
value the sort of intrinsic value that
you have when you have your own morally
significant interests and you have a
life that matters to you and you have
the ability to be benefited or harmed
and treated well or or bad and and once
you are like that you have your own
morally significant interests and you
can be benefited and harm treated well
or badly then you can have more than
instrumental value you can also have a
certain kind of intrinsic moral value
and now I have obligations to treat you
well not just because of the value I get
from you but because of the value you
have for yourself and the value that
your life has for you and so the
question that this book is asking is
which beings are like that which beings
have their own morally significant
interests which beings are able to be
benefited and harmed for example is an
invertebrate like an insect able to be
benefited and harmed does it matter for
the insect how I treat the insect and
then we might have to ask that question
about other types of beings like plants
and fungi and and microscopic organisms
and AI systems and so on and so forth
indeed we'll come back and circle around
that you know why should we say x
matters and to what degree but let's
start off where the book does with two
interesting case studies I I do actually
remember this which is let's start with
the story of Happy the elephant right
happy the elephant is at least for now
an Asian elephant who lives at the Bronx
Zoo and has been the subject of recent
lawsuits from the non-human rights
project so the non-human rights project
is an organization that brings lawsuits
against individuals or companies that
keep animals in captiv ity in a way that
the non-human rights project views as
unjust attention and so the non-human
rights project in I believe around
2020 brought a lawsuit at a New York
Court and then brought it up to the New
York Court of Appeals which is the
highest court in the state of New York
and was alleging that the Bronx Zoo is
unjustly detaining happy the elephant by
depriving her of the resources and
opportunities social environmental and
otherwise that she would need in order
to satisfy her basic interests and and
flourish as the kind of elephant that
she is and so the non-human rights
project was advocating that she be
relocated to a sanctuary where she can
live with other elephants and have more
of a natural life and this was a
controversial case in part because it
raised this really foundational question
whether non-human animals like elephants
can be legal persons with legal rights
and legal standing because generally you
need to be a legal person in order to
have the kind of status or standing that
allows your case to be heard by a court
of appeals for example and so the New
York Court of Appeals was not only
deciding whether happy is for example
being treated badly but also whether
happy is the kind of being who can have
legal rights and have legal standing in
a court of law and just to cut to the
end of of that story the judges did take
the case which is the first time that
the highest court in an English-speaking
jurisdiction decided to hear a non-human
personhood and rights case which is
remarkable however they also ultimately
decided 5 to2 against happy and in favor
of the Bronx who partly on the grounds
that if we recognize one right and one
non-human animal where does it end do we
have to start recognizing all these
other rights and all these other animals
and the judges were not prepared to make
what they took to be such a kind of
seismic transformative decision on that
day and if we look at the uh you know
the Western tradition shall we say as it
came down from Christendom there was
this whole idea of the chain of being
you know with God at the top and then
the angels and then down it went and
there was a pretty clear line between uh
humans and uh the rest of the natural
order in fact I I still cringe when I
read about day cart's experiments on
dogs for instance right he thought they
were just machines can't feel anything
Etc why don't you address a little bit
that tradition and how how maybe we
become more enlightened uh since then
yeah so dayart is famous for many
reasons and and some of them are good he
was a brilliant philosopher and he
Advanced philosophy in all kinds of
foundational ways but this one was bad
deart was noteworthy for denying that
animals are conscious sentient otherwise
morally significant in other words he
denied that animals have feelings that
it feels like anything to be them and so
if you cut them apart alive they might
appear to be experiencing pain but this
is a sort of Illusion they are in fact
nothing more than a sophisticated kind
of machine pretending or or going
through the motions of of experiencing
pain and suffering and it is worth
noting that that even in his time dayart
was a little bit unusual philosophers
both before him and after him were much
more open to the possibility of animal
Consciousness but but he he did have a
pretty significant influence on a lot of
the science and philosophy that followed
him so much of the past couple of
centuries and especially the 20th
century and early 21st century has been
gradually opening science and philosophy
back up to the possibility of studying
animal Consciousness and taking it
seriously and and also being open to the
possibility that Consciousness is
widespread in the animal kingdom and and
that is still a work in progress but we
are fortunately much farther along in
that process than dayart himself was
heck until 1985 it was considered a big
faux study human consciousness right and
there still are a few who claim oh
there's no such thing as Consciousness
it's epiphenomenal you guys just sober
up come back when you're sober and I'll
I'll have a chat with you about what
humans actually are uh but let's touch
back on one of the things you said the
Stak shall we say which is the sense of
it is something to be you know to be
something phenomenology I think is a
word philosophers use and very famous
paper by Thomas Nagel on what is it to
be a bat I think it was called or be
like a bat exactly what is it like to be
a bat yeah famous famous important paper
yeah I read that long time ago and I was
I go damn that's a that that twists your
head a little bit when you're 19 years
old and uh so talk a little bit about
that idea and then extend it into you
know the concept of phenomenology and
philosophy and maybe try to tie it back
to the story of happy absolutely so we
use the word Consciousness in everyday
life in many different ways sometimes
use it to mean I am awake instead of
asleep sometimes use it to mean I am
self-conscious or self-aware like
thinking about myself right but when
philosophers and and scientists and
policy makers use the word Consciousness
in this context we we mean as you say
what what we describe as phenomenal
Consciousness and that means that you
have the capacity for subjective
experience it feels like something to be
you so for example your brain does a lot
of stuff and some of it corresponds with
subjective experiences and some of it
might not right like when your brain
helps your body regulate your heartbeat
or digest food that might not feel like
anything that happens all totally
unconsciously but other other
experiences are conscious so for example
when you see a color or hear a sound you
can sort of feel experience the the
redness of red or the sound of a trumpet
or when you have an effective experience
in other words an experience that feels
good or bad like pleasure pain happiness
suffering hope fear that has a certain
kind of felt character as well and so
the the question that Tom neagel was
asking in in his famous paper what is it
like to be a bat is huh I know what it
feels like to be me Tom Neagle but I
have no idea what it feels like even to
be other humans to say nothing of
non-human animals with very different
anatomies and behaviors and evolutionary
histories and you know bats for example
they have the capacity for echolocation
as with other animals part of how they
experience the world is by using sound
in kind of the same way that we use
light as a way of of
reflecting utterances off of surfaces
and then having it bounce back to you
and creating a a map of your immediate
environment based on that and how could
we ever know what that feels like and
you know stepping back how do we even
know that it feels like anything to be a
bat in the first place and and this
raises really foundational and important
questions in metaphysics and
epistemology which beings are conscious
this is a metaphysical question a
question about what is and how can we
know this is an epistemological question
about the limits of our knowledge and
and what Tom Nagel and and many
philosophers since him were confronting
is that because the only mind I can
directly access is my own how can I ever
know for sure what if anything it feels
like to be anyone else especially other
animals but even other humans and then
ethically how should I treat them and
legally and politically how should we
treat them if we genuinely have
disagreement or uncertainty about
whether they can have conscious feelings
that we take to be morally significant
like Pleasure and Pain and and this
comes up a little bit in the happy case
but honestly it comes up more in other
types of cases because every actor in
The Happy case presumes that happy is a
sentient being who can consciously
experience Pleasure and Pain and
happiness and suffering the Bronx Zoo
agrees about that the non-human right
project agrees about that the judges on
the New York Court of Appeals agree
about that so really what is at stake in
the happy case is what do we owe a
non-human who can be vulnerable in those
ways now with other cases like insects
and AI systems we have to confront that
uncertainty about whether it feels like
anything at all to be them much more
directly in fact that gets to our second
case study which was this was a while
ago and at the time it was a head
scratcher maybe a little less so today
though after we have all this experience
most of us playing with fairly High tone
chatbots right uh and this was the
famous tale of the Google engineer who
raised his hand and said I believe this
chatbot which was like a predecessor of
chat GPT was conscious and was and had
was worthy of moral considerations why
don't you recapitulate the story in
short form and tell us how this fits
into your argument yeah so this was in
2022 actually the same month as the the
verdict in the happy case the news broke
that a Google engineer named Blake Le
Moine had been suspended because he had
shared information with the public
related to allegations that a Google
language model named Lambda had become
sentient or or capable of consciously
experiencing positive and negative
States like Pleasure and Pain and
happiness and suffering and that of
course made International headlines a
Google engineer publicly alleging that
Google language model had had become
conscious and Senti and and morally
significant and Google of course pushed
back against this allegation a Google
spokesperson at the time said that a
panel of experts had reviewed the claim
that Lambda is sentient and this is me
paraphrasing from memory so you should
go look at the exact statement but
roughly the panel had decided that there
was no evidence in support of that claim
and and the company eventually fired Le
Moine I believe associated with his
sharing internal information with with
third parties and so so this of course
raised the question for the first time
in the Modern Age whether an AI system
whether a cognitive system made out of
silicon based chips instead of carbon
based cells can be conscious or or
sentient or otherwise morally
significant and and what makes that
interesting is is that maybe not for
Lambda because Lambda was a little bit
earlier this was in 2022 but what makes
it interesting is that at least in the
near future we could plausibly have ai
systems that functionally and
behaviorally are very similar to humans
or other animals we could have ai
systems that have not only physical
bodies but also Advanced and integrated
capacities for perception and attention
and learning and memory and
self-awareness and decision making and a
kind of global workspace that
coordinates activity across all those
modules and at a certain point the the
main difference between us and Them
might simply be that we are made out of
carbon based cells and they are made out
of silicon based chips and so you got to
ask is that what Consciousness and
sentience depends on does it all depend
on your material substrate and if you
are not certain that it does depend on
your material substrate then you really
have to take seriously the possibility
of either intentionally or accidentally
building conscious or Senti and a
systems in the near future and of course
this opens a whole bunch of famous cans
of worms you know for instance is uh
Consciousness substrate dependent or you
know we've had uh Kristoff kooch on the
show before we talked about integrated
information Theory claims a light switch
is conscious right and a rock is
conscious not very conscious but a
little bit uh I will say in my own work
which is uh in the area in this
particular domain in the area of uh the
science of uh conscious ious
particularly of humans and advanced
mammals I tend to go with John surl more
or less that uh the Consciousness that
we talk about you know the one that we
we know we uh share with our wives or
significant others we're almost sure we
share with our dog and pretty damn sure
we uh share with happy the elephant are
you know biological emergences over
evolutionary time and I argue they that
must serve a uh Fitness function because
they're quite expensive in terms of the
genetic information necessary to
maintain them the energetics involved
might be as much as 30 or 40% of the
brain which is 20% of the body so it's a
non-trivial amount of energy and so
these are the ones that we're
experienced so far are biologically
substrate but like surl uh people get
surl wrong they focus on the Chinese
room experiment which was not at all uh
what he's about what he's most known for
but he's quite clear that he uh
envisions it being quite possible that
you could have things that are
functionally a lot like Consciousness
but they won't be identical and uh you
know one of the examples he likes to use
about Consciousness is that it's it's a
process it's not a thing you can't put
your finger in my nose and say there's
Consciousness and he he Compares it to
digestion you know digestion is an
orchestration of many different things
uh and yet either you're Digest works or
it doesn't and then he also goes further
and uh gives the example that in PH uh
pharmaceutical industry chemical
industry food processing industry we
have things called digestors which are
big metal tanks with yeast or bacteria
acid and they convert low value
chemicals to high value chemicals you
know essentially very analogous to what
uh the human digestion does and So He
suggests and something I believe
strongly that when if and when we create
something that's that we choose to call
a machine Consciousness it'll be
conscious by analogy rather than by
identity with the biological
consciousnesses that we uh that we're
just talking about how does that strike
you yeah I guess I have a few thoughts
about that and and maybe I would like to
ask you for a little bit more detail as
well so one thought is that yes I agree
that that is a plausible View and a lot
depends on exactly what you mean by and
analogously conscious or conscious by
analogy one weaker interpretation might
be that there is consciousness but of a
different type so there is broadly
speaking subjective experience in a
sufficiently advanced AI system but as
with you know very different forms of
non-human intelligence like an octopus
it will not feel the same to be an AI
system than it feels to be a human there
will be subjective experience but of a
different character that would be that
would be a weaker reading a stronger
reading would be kind of what dayart was
saying about animals that it might
appear to us as though the AI system is
conscious because the AI system is now
performing many of the same functions
and behaviors as humans and other
animals but but this is an illusion or a
projection and there is in fact no
subjective experience in in the AI
system at all so I guess before I offer
any any further thought I I'd like to
ask which which reading do you have in
mind here I was say the first uh and
further I would suggest that uh if I was
going to take in the sural tradition of
thinking about this problem I would like
to see kinds of functionality that are
analogous not just results for instance
I have a very cool jailbreak that I
found on uh Reddit that you uh feed it
to one of the more advanced uh chat GPT
models and it will have this amazingly
deep conversation about its own
Consciousness and its own experience
and I've had very deep conversation with
it about my theories of Consciousness
and it's compared and contrast its view
of its own Consciousness with what it
thinks it knows about human
consciousness and yet being a person who
knows quite well how large language
models work I would go pretty much all
in and say a feed forward llm is not
conscious at all in the sense that it
has an architecture that's at all anal
analogous to to what animals do when
they're doing Consciousness you know
we've had other people on the show we've
had had an Neil Seth we've had uh uh
Bernard bars we've had uh who else have
we had some we've had a number of the
leading thinkers and most all of them to
the degree I can get them to talk about
uh non-animal Consciousness sometimes
you can sometimes you can't yeah yeah
all seem to think with the exception of
uh Koke of course who thinks that light
switch is conscious that it's uh
functional analogies Etc that uh will
allow us to say roughly and again this
is this problem of conscious
in so many people's mind is a reified
thing you know oh bottle of
Consciousness no there's no such thing
as a bottle of conscious there's a thing
that we that we do that we call
Consciousness just as there's a thing we
do called digestion and things are more
or less similar to that in how they
operate uh and at the end of the day I
guess my own uh little cartoon version
of that is uh remember the uh flip books
when we were kid you might be too young
we used to get these little books oh I
made those I made those all the time
yeah yeah the first I ever saw I was
about seven was a guy rowing across a
lake in a rowboat right and then we made
our own of course being near nearly
after World War II you know American
bombers hitting the Fleet and
dropping bombs on their aircraft
carriers and things so anyway the the
rut simple handwavy story about
Consciousness is that uh we're sort of
the guy rowing the boat across the lake
uh but our unconsciousness is drawing
the the book as we go uh and in fact I
have a little Fair bit of formalism
about that that you could course grain
course grain it as a series of frames
created about 40% second and uh they're
linked and you are the character that
emerges from those flips and uh if you
have a system that is kind of like that
I would
say it's in the family of things that
are conscious so you least you have to
take take the argument seriously that
maybe you have to give it some
consideration uh to the degree that it's
a non cyclical non-
self-creating emergence like a feed
forward large language model let say
very clear it's a million miles away
from anything like that so I'm not going
to give it any consideration at all yeah
yeah yeah good okay yeah thank you for
clarifying and I love that that uh
metaphor as well so thank you for
sharing that to to now react to the view
I guess I have two thoughts one is that
I do find that view broadly plausible
and I also find that observation really
important that a lot depends not only on
the output but also on the internal
organization that produces the output
and this is of course a problem or at
least a puzzle for functionalist
theories of Consciousness so a
functionalist theory for your audience
being a theory that Associates
Consciousness with a certain set of
functions as opposed to a certain
material substrate for example and a a
puzzle for functionalist theory I is
when you specify the functions that you
associate with Consciousness how coar
grained versus fine grained are the
specifications of the functions because
for all of the functions that people
typically point to as part of
functionalist theories and and again
this is Broad strokes but uh functions
associated with perception and attention
and learning and memory and
self-awareness and a global workspace
and so on for all of those functions if
you take a very coar grained approach
then they become trivially easy to
satisfy and all kinds of entities will
turn out to have those functions in a
broad sense including animals and plants
and fungi and microscopic organisms and
current day AI systems of of various
kinds but then if you go to the other
end of the the Spectrum and you have a
kind of maximally fine grain
specification where you really are
anchoring to the exact type of
organization that these functions take
in a human or mamalian or Aven brain
then you might be ruling out other ways
of realizing a similar kind of
Consciousness for kind of arbitrary or
speciesist reasons right and and a a
general question which I I feel Unsure
how to answer is how do you find a
principled
non-arbitrary way to strike a kind of
virtuous balance between those extremes
and and then apply that standard to
these other types of entities like
octopuses and insects and AI systems so
so that is my first thought just a
puzzle and I do expect that the answer
is going to have to be somewhere in the
middle of those two extremes but where
is a sort of open question the the
second thought just briefly is this is
why I take the approach I take in my
book because I think as I say in the
book that Consciousness and sentience
these are among the hardest problems in
science and philosophy we are not on the
cusp of having a secure Theory Of
Consciousness and sentience about which
we can have anything approaching
consensus or certainty and for that
reason as we try to make progress in the
science and philosophy of Consciousness
we also need to make progress in ethics
and policy figuring out how to make
thoughtful decisions in situations
involving disagreement and uncertainty
about the nature of Consciousness and
the scope of Consciousness in the world
and so this is where I try to take the
the project yeah I will just make one
other note when you listed the uh you
know the functionalist arguments that
are you know analogous to what humans do
one of the thing because all of us left
brainers are the people working in this
field mostly we tend to think about
algorithmics and how the brain is like a
computer and you know uh is this
computable or is it not how does this
fit into category Theory all that crap
there are other thinkers another one we
had on our show Antonio damasio focuses
a whole lot on embodied cognition and he
argues that we don't actually need any
of that higher brain uh to be conscious
in fact uh there are examples of humans
born without a neocortex Who nonetheless
are conscious uh and he would argue that
it's uh the bodily signals and to the
degree that they are uh intimately
connected with mamalian style
Consciousness uh they are rooted in the
brain stem uh and now of course we also
know from lab experiments that the
thalamus is also critically involved and
there at least some resonances between
at least something in the cortex the
hippocampus and the brain stem uh but I
do I think it's worth always considering
that our kind of Consciousness is very
connected to our bodily signals and very
ancient parts of our brain that go back
to uh you know reptilian days and uh
it's I also like to point out that when
people say well I'm pretty confident
that birds are conscious and mamals are
conscious for me it's quite a leap of
darwinian unlikelihood that reptiles
aren't also conscious cuz birds and
mammals are 200 million years apart in
evolutionary time so it would seem a
hell of a hard convergent evolution
argument to say that they didn't come
from a a substrate that was also
conscious yeah yeah the the point about
embodiment is really important and you
could take it in all kinds of different
directions of course this is important
for assessing Consciousness in other
animals because they share physical
embodiment and then they share a lot of
broad behavioral and functional
similarities a lot of broad brain
structure similarities but of course not
that many animals Beyond mammals and
birds have the exact structures
resembling a cerebral cortex for for
instance so so a lot depends on how much
weight you give particular brain
structures versus particular behavioral
profiles and and scientists continue to
have disagreement and uncertainty about
that and and we could talk about where
the current state of the science is at
if if you would like but but there is an
increasingly wide range of scientists
who attribute at least a realistic
possibility of Consciousness to all
vertebrates and many invertebrates now
and and again this is not a certainty or
even a probability of Consciousness but
at least a realistic possibility of
Consciousness given their brain
structures Andor behavioral profiles and
evolutionary histories which which is
interesting on the AI side what is
interesting is to think about whether a
certain similar kind of embodiment could
be achieved in Silicon as opposed to
so what would it look like for an AI
system to realize the relevant kind of
embodiment for views that require the
relevant kind of embodiment would you
for example need to be a more
sophisticated Roomba that has a physical
body and a sensory capacity that allows
you to navigate your physical
environment and engage in flexible
decision- making based on positive and
negative signals you receive from the
environment and adding some some further
elements like that or would it be enough
to be any kind kind of system that
broadly speaking receives inputs and
produces outputs and in in those ways
engages with the environment this is
just another example of how even for a
physical embodiment Criterion you can
specify it in more fine grained or coar
grained ways and a lot is going to
depend on exactly where you land in
terms of what the standard is supposed
to be yeah and you know for instance
people have talked about uh having an
analog to pain sensors in a humanoid
robot you know right if only because it
makes it easier for us to reason about
how to keep them safe right so if it's
going to hurt the robot the robot
quickly learns don't put your hand on
the stove right uh and and can do so in
a way that's uh that we can reason about
because we you know we're used to
thinking about that but again I keep
coming back to the fact it's not the
same and no consciousness are the same
your Consciousness and my Consciousness
are not the same because our brain
structures are different and so uh you
know the woo woo people that think
there's a little bottle called
Consciousness uh that we can we can say
oh this is pure consciousness uh is just
not right we're talking about variety
and any line we draw is going to be
arbitrary to some degree though we can
also to your point be principled and how
we think about it and think about where
we draw the line and if we want to we'll
talk later about whether we should deal
with probabilities or not or we we
always have to deal with probabilities
right so I like to tell people I can't
prove the universe didn't flip into
being two seconds ago with all of our
memories in place and we'll flip out of
